title: `File not found error` for tsx file when calling MCP tools that return embedded resources
body: - Copilot Chat Extension Version: - VS Code Version: : 1.105.0-insider (Universal) - OS Version: Darwin arm64 24.6.0 - Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent mode - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): GPT5-mini - Logs: Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open Copilot Chat 2. Setup remote GitHub MCP server 3. Disable all tools except for `get_file_contents` 4. Ask Copilot to get content of a file from a repo

title: Element with ID all open already registered error
body: 1. git clone https://github.com/isidorn/growth-lab.git 2. npm install && npm run dev 3. "Clicking on the New Experiment button does not do anything. Think and create a short but effective plan on how to fix that." 4. Wait until plan comes. "Looks good, now go ahead and implement that". Fire off to remote agent 5. Open GitHub PR view -> sometimes I get this error (about 40% of the times) and the view does not render Looks like we are using the same id for the tree element. Might it be that we compute the id from the PR title - and the pr title is the same? Since i was practigin a demo. Should we also take into account the PR # id when generating a tree it to make it unique? fyi @bamurtaugh

title: Resolving to the current workspace root in the workspace config file.
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

This is similar, but definitely not the same as #50372. I understand that resolving to the location of the workspace file (or its directory) doesn't make sense, however, what should make sense in this file is resolving to the location of the current root in a multiple-root workspace.

For example, I have this for the debugger:

```javascript
{
	"name": "Python Debugger: Remote",
	"type": "debugpy",
	"request": "attach",
	"connect": {
		"host": "localhost",
		"port": 5678
	},
	// It needs to know all the source dirs
	"pathMappings": [
		{
			"localRoot": "${workspaceFolder}/src",
			"remoteRoot": "src" // ./src doesn't work
		},
		{
			"localRoot": "${workspaceFolder}/tests",
			"remoteRoot": "tests"
		}
	],
	"justMyCode": false // Consider 'remote' code too
}
```

I have to add a launcher like this to each root I have in my workspace, because if I add it straight to the workspace file, it will force me to specify the root I want with `${workspaceFolder:myproject}`.

If I had something with the semantics: the root is the root of the current file or the selected root in the explorer, I could have just one configuration for all the roots.

This could be done in one of these ways:

* Add this semantics when `${workspaceFolder}` is used in the workspace file
* Add a special name after the colon in `workspaceFolder`, eg, `${workspaceFolder:$current}`
* Add a new variable like `${currentRootFolder}`

Sorry if any of the above exists; I've searched for it, without success.

title: Copy selection for deleted chunk in inline diff
body:
An attempt to fix #8226 

Hi @hediet , can I interest you with (yet another) PR for #8226, a.k.a. inline diff deleted chunk copy selection? :)

The main idea is to calculate the exact line and column for the start & end of the selection in a view zone, and extract the corresponding code chunk using the text model API.

Demo: 
![copySelectionInlineDelete](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1b64cec2-aed4-4e39-9b5f-854cf3f06c83)

This works with both the menu item, and the browser 'copy' event (Ctrl/Cmd+C).

I have put the setup in a reusable method in a separate file, following the example of [renderLines.ts](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/src/vs/editor/browser/widget/diffEditor/components/diffEditorViewZones/renderLines.ts)

Due to the view zone, there are some hackery involved to get those line and column numbers right (the line number extraction is the same as that from the [inlineDiffDeletedCodeMargin.ts](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/src/vs/editor/browser/widget/diffEditor/components/diffEditorViewZones/inlineDiffDeletedCodeMargin.ts)). Let me know if you see any issues, or if you prefer to solve it in a different way.

Thanks!


<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

title: Copilot Instruction generation path issue.
body:
Type: Bug The Copilot auto-generated instruction prompt currently references an incorrect file path, which prevents the intended configuration from being recognized and applied. Specifically, it points to .github/copilot-instructions.md, whereas the correct and functional path should be .github/instructions/copilot-instructions.md. This discrepancy means that Copilot fails to locate the instruction file during initialization, resulting in the absence of custom behavior or guidance that the file is meant to enforce. Since Copilot relies on precise directory structure and naming conventions to detect and apply user-defined instructions, even a minor misplacement like this renders the configuration ineffective. To resolve the issue, ensure that the copilot-instructions.md file is nested within the instructions subdirectory inside .github, like so: .github/ └── instructions/ └── copilot-instructions.md Once the file is correctly placed, Copilot will be able to parse and apply the instructions as intended, enabling tailored responses and behavior based on your specifications. VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (Universal) (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Darwin arm64 24.6.0 Modes:

title: Provide a way to disable the extension trust prompt (Do you trust the publisher "XYZ"?)

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
There is a new trust prompt when someone wants to install an extension, but there is no way of disabling it.

As @isidorn pointed out on [reddit](https://www.reddit.com/r/vscode/comments/1ilasjv/new_vscode_extension_trust_system/) this prompt is to educate people that extensions run with the same privilege as vscode, which can be exploited by malicious actors.

This is cool, but most people will just blindly click "Trust publisher & install" anyway, and after a few times this prompt just gets annoying.\
Very few people will check the source code and build the vsix file manually to install it... maybe 0.\
Even if someone checks the source code from the repository link and installs the extension from the store, there is no guarantee that the extension was built from that specific repository and not some similar but malicious one (of course you can compare them after it's installed).

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/be160613-138e-4ac1-857e-0725eb961b5a)
